Award.AwardTitle: Data Analysis Techniques for the Epoch of Reionization and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
Joshua Dillon is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the University of California, Berkeley. Dillon will develop analysis techniques to enhance the sensitivity of large radio telescope arrays. This will allow astronomers to detect gas from a time when the first stars formed in the Universe and influenced the formation of objects such as galaxies and black holes. Alongside this research, Dillon will develop a course in data science for undergraduate astronomy research students.

Dillon will create new foreground subtraction and baseline calibration techniques for the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array experiment (HERA), which aims to detect hydrogen from the Epoch of Reionization (EoR). He will also develop and assess designs for future radio telescope arrays to capitalize on these techniques. For the educational component of his work, Dillon will develop a course in data science for undergraduate students participating in HERA's summer research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While the last century has seen a revolution in our understanding of the history and composition of our Universe, the vast majority of the observable volume of our Universe remains unobserved. 21 cm Cosmology is a new technique to use radio emissions from hydrogen, the most abundant element, to one day make the largest-ever 3D maps of our Universe. Studying the statistical properties of these maps will help us understand how stars, black holes, and galaxies formed and evolved and perhaps elucidate the nature of the mysterious dark matter and dark energy that make up the majority of the mass in the Universe. 

The goal of this project was to develop and apply new techniques for analyzing data from radio telescopes designed specifically for 21 cm Cosmology.  In particular, I focused on HERA, the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array, so-named because it is designed to detect the signal from hydrogen in the gas between galaxies during the first billion years of the Universe during a time when galaxies and black holes were emitting ionizing radiation and turning that gas into an ionized plasma. HERA, an NSF-funded array in South Africa, is currently under construction and will have 350 14-m dishes when finished. We’re looking for radio waves near FM frequencies, so arrays like HERA need to be built far away from population centers.

This project focuses on developing new techniques for analyzing massive quantities of data from radio telescopes like HERA and its potential successors. The main challenge of this work is the so-called “foregrounds,” radio emission from our galaxy and other galaxies that are much closer than the source of the 21 cm signal and roughly 100,000 times brighter. The key to separating the 21 cm signal from the foregrounds is by looking at many frequencies of radio waves and trying to remove the smooth-spectrum foregrounds, leaving only 21 cm signal. By way of an analogy to music, we’re trying to filter off an overwhelmingly loud bass so we can hear the faint treble. 

Maintaining the separability of 21 cm foregrounds relies on a precise understanding of the real-world complexities of how well our telescope is performing. Unfortunately, miscalibration can make foregrounds look like signal and thus make the true signal undetectable. This work was focused on building and testing new algorithms and new software, both on simulated data and on real data, for maintaining that separability and therefore maximizing the scientific potential of HERA and similar telescopes. This work led to several peer-reviewed scientific publications and underlies important upcoming work from the HERA collaboration on  what our observations tell us about the state of the universe less than a billion years after the Big Bang. 

The advanced statistical and data science techniques necessary for this research also represented a major opportunity to develop the technical skills of many undergraduate and graduate students working on HERA. As part of this grant, I led curriculum development for the CHAMP Bootcamp, part of the California-Arizona Minority Partnership for Astronomy Research and Education (CAMPARE) program. This week-long educational program kicked off a summer of undergraduate research opportunities on HERA for students from California State Universities and California Community Colleges, helping them get the necessary background to make meaningful contributions to the project. Supplementing this program, I took some of the key data science, statistics, and python coding skills that my students needed and developed a program of problem sets and office hours to teach those skills in parallel with the summer research experience. The material for those lessons and problem sets is available publicly at https://github.com/HERA-Team/CHAMP_Bootcamp.
